column9: Days After Onset/Admission (+) Covid-19 Presence (maximum unless otherwise stated)

column3: The presence of SARS‐CoV‐2 RNA in the feces of COVID‐19 patients
column11: A total of 28 (66.67%) patients tested positive for SARS‐CoV‐2 RNA in stool specimens, and this was not associated with the presence. Among them, 18 (64.29%) patients remained positive for viral RNA in the feces after the pharyngeal swabs turned negative. The duration of viral shedding from the feces after negative conversion in pharyngeal swabs was 7 (6‐10) days, regardless of COVID‐19 severity.

column3: Digestive Symptoms in COVID-19 Patients With Mild Disease Severity: Clinical Presentation, Stool Viral RNA Testing, and Outcomes.
column11: Twelve (54.5%) of these patients tested positive for viral RNA in stool. ; We found that compared with patients with only respiratory symptoms, those with digestive symptoms tend to have a longer course between symptom onset and viral clearance and are more likely to test positive for COVID-19 viral RNA in the stool, suggesting (but not confirming) direct infectivity of the virus on the intestinal tract.

column3: Virus shedding patterns in nasopharyngeal and fecal specimens of COVID-19 patients
column11: These results indicated that beside respiratory samples, intestinal samples (e.g. feces) should be recommended for diagnosis of COVID-19,especially for monitoring the relapse of discharged patients. ; The viral titers of nasal-throat swabs peaked at six to nine d.a.o. and at 14-18 d.a.o for fecal samples, and the highest virus titers at the peak was significantly higher for feces.

column3: Prolonged Viral Shedding in Feces of Pediatric Patients with Coronavirus Disease 2019
column5: Journal of Microbiology, Immunology and Infection
column11: Persistent shedding of SARS-CoV-2 in stools of infected children raises the possibility that the virus might be transmitted through contaminated fomites. ; Detection of SARS-CoV-2 in fecal specimens should be considered as one of the routine diagnostic tests to guide decision-making on hospital discharge and release of isolation

column3: Viral Kinetics and Antibody Responses in Patients with COVID-19
column11: Nasopharyngeal, sputum and stools rather than blood and urine, were the major shedding routes for SARS-CoV-2, and meanwhile sputum had a prolonged viral shedding.

column3: Do children need a longer time to shed SARS-CoV-2 in stool than adults?
column5: Journal of Microbiology, Immunology and Infection
column11: Compared with respiratory specimens, stool specimens may remain positive longer, similar to the findings of the present study.;Children show a longer shedding time than adults.

column3: Prolonged Presence of SARS-CoV-2 Viral RNA in faecal samples
column11: Respiratory samples remained positive for SARS-CoV-2 RNA for a mean of 16·7 days (SD 6·7) and faecal samples remained positive for a mean of 27·9 days (10·7) after first symptom onset (ie, for a mean of 11·2 days [9·2] longer than for respiratory samples).

column3: Evaluation of SARS-CoV-2 RNA shedding in clinical specimens and clinical characteristics of 10 patients with COVID-19 in Macau
column11: There were positive SARS-CoV-2 RNA signals in all patients' NPS and stool specimens but negative in all urine specimens. Based on our data on SARS-CoV-2 RNA shedding in stool and the possibility of a lag in viral detection in NPS specimens, the assessment of both fecal and respiratory specimen is recommended to enhance diagnostic sensitivity, and also to aid discharge decision before the role of viral RNA shedding in stool is clarified. ; fecal samples were subsequently collected and virus RNA were detectable in 90% of our patients from their first sample by qRT-PCR.

column3: Clinical presentation and virological assessment of hospitalized cases of coronavirus disease 2019 in a travel-associated transmission cluster
column11: Stool and sputum samples remained RNA-positive over even longer periods, in spite of full resolution of symptoms.

column3: Epidemiologic Features and Clinical Course of Patients Infected With SARS-CoV-2 in Singapore
column11: In 4 of 8 patients, virus was detected in stool, regardless of diarrhea, over 1 to 7 days.

column3: Fecal specimen diagnosis 2019 novel coronavirus–infected pneumonia
column11: In our cases, we found that patients with a positive stool test did not experience gastrointestinal symptoms and had nothing to do with the severity of the lung infection.

column3: Evidence for gastrointestinal infection of SARS-CoV-2
column11: Of all the 73 SARS-CoV-2-infected patients, 39 (53.42%) including 25 males and 14 females tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 RNA in stool ; 17 (23.29%) patients remained positive in stool after showing negative in respiratory samples.
